entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 10} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}17 ({@damage 3d6 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 10} to hit, range 30/120 ft., one target. {@h}34 ({@damage 5d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Frenzy {@recharge 5}
entries: The cyclops makes four claw attacks against one target. After these attacks, the cyclops gains 3 ({@dice 1d6}) temporary hit points for every attack that hit.

An aarakocra captain is, as its name describes, the captain of an aarakocra warband. Proven combatants and inspiring leaders, aarakocra captains lead their tribe's warriors into battle against their enemies, and quickly muster a defense when their tribes are attacked. A captain of an aarakocra warband is generally chosen on the basis of merit, where the strongest among the tribe fiercely compete for the position.

In battle, a captain leads their troops using hand signals and short phrases, organizing them into formations. They do not stay at the back for long, however. Once a battle starts they quickly charge into the fray with their long, yet surprisingly light lance. Their dive attacks leave enemies vulnerable to incoming attacks from the captain's troops, allowing them to quickly dive in and make their own strike.

entries.name: Aarakocra
entries: The small tribes of Aarakocra that dot the Elemental Plane of Air and the other worlds of D&D are made up of both fierce warbands and priestly orders devoted to their goddess, {@deity Aerdrie Faenya|Elven|MTF}. While most Aarakocra worship Aerdrie, a small number of tribes worship other gods and goddesses as well.

In order to create a well-balanced warband, a variety of both melee and ranged troops are necessary. This is where the aarakocra sharpshooters come in. Highly skilled with the longbow, these warriors make effective skirmishers that can greatly augment the effectiveness of a warband. Among the aarakocra, sharpshooters are the most nimble flyers. They are trained from a young age to fly with great dexterity, allowing them to easily evade their enemy's grasp.

entries.name: Aarakocra
entries: The small tribes of Aarakocra that dot the Elemental Plane of Air and the other worlds of D&D are made up of both fierce warbands and priestly orders devoted to their goddess, {@deity Aerdrie Faenya|Elven|MTF}. While most Aarakocra worship Aerdrie, a small number of tribes worship other gods and goddesses as well.

Aerdrie Faenya, also known as the Winged Mother or the Lady of Air and Wind, is the goddess that most aarakocra worship. She is an elvish goddess, and the primary patron of the avariel, or winged elves.

Aarakocra priests of Aerdrie have been visited and granted power by Aerdrie herself, who appeared to them as a brilliant white bird to grant them her blessing. Only the most accomplished among the aarakocra priesthood receive Aerdrie's blessing, which grants them the innate magical ability to manipulate and animate air to do their will.

Priests of Aerdrie often act as assistants to the tribe's leader, and they may take over the leader's responsibilities if they were to meet an unfortunate end. As the mouthpiece of their goddess, priests of Aerdrie are some of the most powerful individuals in aarakocra society.

entries.name: Aarakocra
entries: The small tribes of Aarakocra that dot the Elemental Plane of Air and the other worlds of D&D are made up of both fierce warbands and priestly orders devoted to their goddess, {@deity Aerdrie Faenya|Elven|MTF}. While most Aarakocra worship Aerdrie, a small number of tribes worship other gods and goddesses as well.

The abolethic sovereignty consists of the eldest aboleths, beings that existed in the Far Realm back when the world was young and the gods absent. They came to the material plane though no plans of their own, as their great city, Xxiphu, plummeted from the Far Realm into the primordial oceans of the world.

Since then, the aboleth sovereigns have long dissociated themselves with the other aboleths of the realms, who regard them with both fear and disdain. Far older than the other aboleths, aboleth sovereigns have different thought patterns and beliefs that set them apart from their cousins.

entries.name: An Aboleth Sovereign's Lair
entries: Aboleth sovereigns make their lair in the deepest depths of the ocean, where their ancient cities and obelisks have existed since the beginning of time. It is here where they spend the majority of their existence, plotting their revenge against the gods.

Aboleths never truly die. When an aboleth's body is destroyed, its spirit returns to the elemental plane of water, mind and memories intact. Over a period of days or even months, a new body coalesces for the aboleth. When first recreated, the aboleth's body is greatly weakened and vulnerable. During this time the aboleth is considered "young," though that isn't entirely true. While the aboleth's body may be underdeveloped, its mind is still eternal and unforgetting.

If an aboleth's body is destroyed during this time, the time it takes to coalesce is increased. While an aboleth killed fully grown often regenerates over a few days or weeks, an aboleth killed in this state may take months to reform.
Savage creatures with a misshapen but humanoid upper body and a shaggy, dog-like lower body, adlets are reviled by other humanoids for their uncivilized, murderous nature.

Legend tells of adlets being the perverse offspring of human and beast, taller and stronger than either of their parents. Whatever their origin may be, adlets are known to other humanoids as simple, uncivilized creatures, constantly roaming the snowy wilderness they call home in search of food. Adlets prefer the taste of humanoids, but they also hunt other beasts if necessary, and even resort to cannibalism in particularly harsh winters. They hunt in disorganized packs, ambushing whatever unfortunate soul they come across and then eating them alive.

entries.name: Bloodlust
entries: Some adlets carry a disease called adlet bloodlust. While the disease isn't harmful to the adlet, it can be easily transferred to a bitten humanoid. Once infected, the diseased creature begins to thirst for humanoid blood and hunger for the flesh of its kin.

While the disease can be easily cured by a lesser restoration or simply time in bed, if left untreated it can easily devastate a community. The infected may attempt to eat other humanoids they find, either killing them or spreading the disease farther. If they stay inside, a diseased creature may die of thirst due to vomiting up any liquid they consume that isn't humanoid blood.

The ahklut is a massive, shapeshifting predator that scours the coldest oceans of the world, seeking prey to sate its hunger. These creatures spend most of their time in the form of a orca, where their only distinctive quality is their increased muscle mass and swiftness. Their more recognizable form, and the form that most civilized creatures encounter, is their hybrid form. Like a cross between a dire wolf and an orca, an ahklut's true form is extraordinarily strong and swift, and can easily chase down and kill even the most formidable land creatures

entries.name: Ambush Predator
entries: An ahklut prefers to hunt land creatures, rather than marine ones. When it gets hungry, it stalks the coastal waters and rivers of its territory, searching for animals that have come to drink. Once it finds a creature, it leaps out of the water and takes them by surprise. Its primary weapons are its powerful bite and deadly claws, but against weaker creatures it will often throw its prey into the water and drown it.

entries.name: Sea Titans
entries: The small tribes that dot the arctic areas of the world often begin to think of an ahklut as an almost divine entity. Their enormous size and fierce nature make them seem like angry spirits, sent down from a cruel god as punishment. While these views are unfounded, they are popular among the more remote tribes of the world.

In some cases, humanoids attempt to tame these great beasts. A particularly large goliath, made confident from their successes, might attempt to force an ahklut into submission, taking it as their mount. While stories like that have occasionally ended in success, in the vast majority of cases an ahklut can overpower and kill even an entire village of mighty warriors. But in the rare cases that they are tamed, ahkluts make some of the most fearsome mounts imaginable. Strong, swift, and capable of traveling on both land and sea, these creatures are almost unmatched in their strength and versatility.

An agathion is a lesser angel, far weaker than the angels formed from shards of the divine. Instead created from the souls of benevolent humanoids, agathions are given their angelic form as a reward for the good deeds they performed in life. Embodying the concepts of peace and goodness, agathions bring order and justice to those they encounter.

When a mortal soul becomes an agathion, it gains a bestial aspect that takes the form of a creature that exemplifies their personality. Many agathions choose to stay in this beastial form for most of their time, silently watching over mortals and only taking on their true form when there is judgement to be done.

Valkyries are the divine agents of war gods and gods of victory and courage. Almost always female, a valkyrie appears as a strong and beautiful human or elf with long flowing hair and pure white wings.
Hosts of valkyries join battles at the command of their gods, where they shift the tides of war, inspiring heroism in their allies and enacting vengeance upon their foes.
This intricately crafted staff, adorned with a glowing orb filled with magical power, dances through the air casting powerful spells as a conduit of its creator's power.

entries.name: Arcane Orb
entries: Every animator's staff has an arcane orb, which stores its magical power. If destroyed, the staff drops to the ground and becomes inanimate. A new orb can then be crafted for the staff, allowing it to transfer to a new owner. Crafting an orb requires 1 week, costs 1000 gp in components, and requires the casting of any spells it will be imbued with.

entries.name: Animated Objects
entries: Crafted with potent magic, animated objects are used in the service of powerful spellcasters as guards for their strongholds and towers.

This small, wooden wand dances through the air, casting weak spells at its creator's command. Weak and not particularly hardy, an animator's wand most often serves as a distraction rather than an actual threat. Unlike the more powerful staves, a wand cannot regain spell slots through a long rest.

entries.name: Animated Objects
entries: Crafted with potent magic, animated objects are used in the service of powerful spellcasters as guards for their strongholds and towers.
Merely an animated spike, a flying caltrop isn't much of a threat on its own. When encountered in groups, however, these constructs can be quite formidable.

entries.name: Animated Objects
entries: Crafted with potent magic, animated objects are used in the service of powerful spellcasters as guards for their strongholds and towers.

Rarely found alone, a flying shield rushes to the defense of its allies, where it begins to fight with them in perfect unison. While mainly used for the defense of other creatures and animated objects, a flying shield also bashes into its opponents with great strength.
Often paired with a flying sword, this combination creates an animated unit that fights like a single warrior

entries.name: Animated Objects
entries: Crafted with potent magic, animated objects are used in the service of powerful spellcasters as guards for their strongholds and towers.

This hardy burlap sack is programmed to fly at an opponent's head, covering their eyes and blinding them, opening them up for attack. While simple in design, these animations can prove especially deadly. Once they latch on to a creature's head, they can be particularly hard to remove without endangering the creature beneath.

entries.name: Animated Objects
entries: Crafted with potent magic, animated objects are used in the service of powerful spellcasters as guards for their strongholds and towers.

monsterFluff.name: Jungle Ankheg
entries: In the jungles of the world, some ankhegs have adapted themselves to this new, harsh wilderness. Tested and honed by hosts of deadly creatures, these ankhegs have become a much more fearsome foe to face.

Found in remote jungles and ancient swamps, a jungle ankheg is a fearsome predator that burrows through the dark undergrowth and loose earth. Resembling a large, sickly green insect with long, sharp claws and deadly mandibles, this creature has adapted to its environment over many generations, While still quite similar to regular ankhegs, a jungle ankheg is slightly larger, its legs are longer and thinner, and it has a distinct green color.

entries.name: Solitary Hunters
entries: While regular ankhegs are often found in groups, jungle ankhegs are more solitary in nature, meeting up only about once every six months to mate. Even so, these creatures manage to create vast arrays of small earthen tunnels for themselves, allowing them to hunt their prey with ease while solidifying their hold on their territory.

When a jungle ankheg hunts, it utilizes a powerful acid to dissolve its prey before eating it. As the ankheg gets older, this acid even seeps into their bloodstream, making their wounds spray acid at attackers. A single jungle ankheg contains enough of this acidic compound to create around 30 vials of acid.

entries.name: Hard Carapace
entries: A jungle ankheg carapace is a sought after treasure. Hard yet light and flexible, this material can be utilized by talented armorsmiths to make a breastplate.

An azer artisan, renowned for their skill with the hammer, toils away at their work in hot, smoke-filled smithies. While they aren't trained warriors, their strong arms and masterfully crafted weapons make them hard opponents to face when a creature gets on their bad side.

entries.name: Skills for Hire
entries: If asked politely (with "politely" implying a large amount of money), an azer artisan might lend a buyer their skills. Capable of creating and enchanting weapons and armor, an azer artisan may be willing to create the item featured under "Master Crafted Weapons" in its statblock.
Tough and charismatic, an azer lord is intimidating beyond their small stature. As the leader of a city or similar establishment, they need to be a strong face for their people.
Also accomplished warriors and war leaders, azer lords lead their armies into battle when necessary. On the battlefield they lead from the front, inspiriting their men and felling the enemy.

The baku are powerful fey spirits, resembling a cross between an elephant, a lion, and other assorted beasts. Also called "dream eaters," these creatures lurk in the fringes of civilization, seeking out sleeping creatures to feed off of.

A baku is born from either a particularly good dream or an unusually bad nightmare, and its disposition in life is based on the circumstances of its creation. Baku that are born from good dreams seek to cleanse the nightmares and heal the minds of those they encounter, while baku born from nightmares seek to consume good dreams, killing all they encounter in the process.

entries.name: Protectors and Destroyers
entries: A good-natured baku will often become attached to a particular village, and attempt to protect its residents, eating their nightmares and killing those that seek to harm them. The baku may even talk with the members of its village, appearing in their dreams and reassuring them after nightmares. Members of a village may even summon the baku to stay with them if they think they are going to have a nightmare, and the baku is usually glad to grant their request. More often, however, they act as silent guardians, helping in discreet ways and disappearing into the night when their job is done.

Evil baku, on the other hand, do the exact opposite. When they encounter a village, they slowly kill off its residents one at a time. When none remain, they move on to the next village and continue the process, only stopping when they are defeated or scared off by a more powerful opponent

monsterFluff.name: Bewailer
entries: Banshees are spiteful creatures formed from the spirits of female elves. Occasionally, one of these spirits is instead formed as a bewailer, a creature that exists in a state of constant agony and anguish.

Like perfect clockwork, a bewailer's woeful cries can be heard at the same time each and every day, haunting an area with their presence. Not bound by the night like regular banshees, bewailers are sometimes called daywraiths. This name isn't perfectly accurate, however—a bewailer can potentially be present at any time of day, and the only thing that determines that time is their time of death. For example, a bewailer that died at 3 pm would be active from 2 pm to 4 pm, while one that died at 2 am would be active from 1 am to 3 am.

entries.name: Divine Curse
entries: A bewailer, like the banshee, was once a female elf that became afflicted with the banshee's curse. The only real difference that causes a creature inflicted with the curse to instead become a bewailer is their cause of death. A bewailer is formed when the cursed creature is driven to commit suicide, completing their transformation into an undead monster.
The bewailer appears as a white-skinned, frail spirit that closely resembles their mortal form. Their cause of death is often quite obvious, displayed by the marks along their neck.

The serpentine greater basilisk is one of the most fearsome creatures a traveler might come across. Far larger and more dangerous than its closely-related cousin, a greater basilisk is feared not just for its petrifying gaze and terrifying size, but also for its potent venom.

The poison of a greater basilisk can be delivered through its bite, as well as through the two prongs at the end of its tail. It can also spit its poison a considerable distance, covering a creature and splashing the surrounding area. As deadly as these creatures are, this venom is often sought after by hunters and adventurers for its use in poisons and alchemical compounds.

entries.name: Apex Predators
entries: Greater basilisks usually make their lairs in coastal caves, from which they patrol the surrounding area for potential meals. Far more intelligent than its cousins, greater basilisks often "tame" lesser basilisks, using them as guards for their lairs in exchange for protection and food.

A greater basilisk born and raised in captivity can be domesticated and trained, but doing so is a far harder task than training a regular basilisk. However, a properly trained greater basilisk is one of the most effective guardians around, so their eggs go for exorbitant prices.

entries.name: Gaze of Stone
entries: A greater basilisk's supernatural gaze is able to turn creatures to stone instantaneously. Then they consume their meals in much the same way a regular basilisk does, except they are able to hunt much larger prey. It is not uncommon to find a stone statue of a huge beast near the lair of a greater basilisk.
The fluids within the greater basilisk's gullet are able to produce an oil capable of returning petrified creatures to life, just like its smaller cousins.

entries.name: Basilisks
entries: Basilisks are adaptive and varied predators, and they come in many different forms, with some of those forms being much more powerful than regular basilisks.

Bright blue in color and monstrous in its demeanor, a marine basilisk is a rare variation of the ground-dwelling basilisk. Adapted to the environment of the great oceans and lakes of the world, these creatures are skilled swimmers and are surprisingly quiet in the water. Their bodies are large and streamlined, like the body of a crocodile.

entries.name: Petrifying Water
entries: A marine basilisk has petrifying enzymes within its stomach that it can release after inhaling a large amount of water. This deadly mixture is able to petrify any creature that it touches, allowing a marine basilisk to hunt prey that doesn't look at it. This is especially useful for marine basilisks that hunt in the deep sea, as many creatures there are naturally blind.

entries.name: Sea Hunter
entries: As marine basilisks almost exclusively hunt underwater, they don't have the same warning signs that terrestrial basilisks have. Most of their prey is small enough to be eaten whole after the petrification process, and the creatures that aren't just sink to the bottom of whatever body of water the basilisk hunts in, making it hard to see the typical warning signs of a basilisk.

entries.name: Basilisks
entries: Basilisks are adaptive and varied predators, and they come in many different forms, with some of those forms being much more powerful than regular basilisks.

monsterFluff.name: Plated Behir
entries: Behirs are powerful cavern predators, known for their long, snake-like bodies and their deadly lightning breath. Some behirs have gained certain mutations, making them stronger, or weaker, than their kin.

A plated behir is a genetic mutation that is results in larger, thicker scales across its body, like a personalized coat of pale blue plating. These creatures are more slender than their kin, and their hard plating makes their gullet less flexible than that of a normal behir. These variations mean that they are incapable of safely swallowing large prey whole, forcing them to use other methods of taking down their foes.

Plated behirs are more proficient in their lightning-based abilities, which they can manipulate to create alternate effects to the basic lightning breath that behirs are known for. These creatures can also charge their metallic plating with electricity, making themselves momentarily stronger and faster after they attack with their lightning.

entries.name: Solitary Hunters
entries: Plated behirs are often shunned by other behir, and they often never find a mate unless they are lucky enough to come across another of their kind. Their dragon-like appearance makes other behir wary of their presence, and some may even go as far as hunting them down.

entries.name: Valued Hides
entries: The plates of a plated behir are a valued commodity, due their their applications in armor making. Adventurers that think they're powerful enough to take one down will often go to great lengths to secure its hide, which can be sold for high prices or forged into lightning-resistant plate armor.

An eye of the deep is a lesser beholder that might come into being when a beholder has a nightmare of drowning in the depths of the ocean. The creature has only two eye stalks, with its other two replaced by crab-like pincers. It slightly resembles the shape of the beholder that dreamed it into existence, but it is covered in a colorful chitin and has a mouth filled with rows of teeth.

entries.name: Coastal Menace
entries: An eye of the deep terrorizes whatever body of water it ends up in, destroying and consuming the natural wildlife and harassing any seaside settlements that are unfortunate enough to be near it. While it mostly remains underwater, terrorizing ships and other vessels, an eye of the deep often ventures onto the shore for short periods of time in order to find new victims.

entries.name: A Light in the Depths
entries: The central eye of the eye of the deep emits a glaringly bright magical light that can light up even magical darkness. This light can be used to attract the prey that instinctively swim towards it, to their own demise. A creature that comes too close to this light becomes temporarily blinded by its brightness. It is at this point that the eye of the deep attacks unleashing its claws and eye rays upon its unfortunate victim.

Appearing as a mass of dead branches and thorny brambles, a bramble blight is a particularly potent version of the blight. Capable of speech, these blights act as warriors and pseudo-leaders to the other blights. Unlike others of their kind, a bramble blight creates weapons that it imbues with the deadly poison that courses throughout its body.

Travelers who happen upon a branch blight rarely live to tell the tale. Large and malevolent, these creatures prowl blighted forests with a mindless appetite for violence. Other, smaller blights often flock to their side, using their immense strength as a means of protection.

Tall and bipedal, a wood blight might be mistaken for a human traveler in the dim light. Upon closer inspection, their bark covered, wooden form becomes obvious. The creatures that get this close are soon met with the blind rage of the wood blight.

Highly trained and extremely capable, a bugbear assassin is a force to be reckoned with. While all bugbears are naturally stealthy, these individuals have honed that ability to become some of the most sought after assassins, especially among the other goblinoid races. Often found under the employment of a troop of hobgoblins, a bugbear assassin is able to dispatch even some of the most powerful foes they might encounter.

This effectiveness comes at a cost, however. A bugbear assassin often asks for large payments to be made up front for it to even consider taking a job, and they are quick to betray their allies if a better offer presents itself.

A bugbear champion of Hruggek has been blessed by that feared god of war, gifted with great strength and the ability to cast divine magic. These champions act as war priests, marching into the front lines to both wreak havoc and protect their allies from harm. They often take on more of a supportive role than their allies, using spells like hold person and spiritual weapon to control the battle.

The highest member in the aristocracy, a bullywug chief has fought hard and long to rise to its position of relative splendor. These chiefs often give themselves grand sounding titles and take a large amount of the loot that their tribe acquires, making them quite well off. They often grow fat through laziness and gluttony, which may eventually lead to their downfall as they become too weak to hold on to their position.
Armed with large mauls, a weapon that only the strong can wield, a bullywug chief can make a fierce combatant.

entries.name: Bullywugs
entries: Brutish, frog-like amphibians, bullywugs are a primitive race of hunter gatherers, held together by a corrupt aristocracy and caste system. Bullywug society is defined by these separate castes, and a bullywug in a lower caste always tries to improve its station.

One of the lowests castes, a bullywug hunter can only go up in life. While they officially go out of the tribe to hunt for food, many of these hunters become makeshift adventurers, hunting for treasures that they can bring to their chieftain in exchange for gaining a higher status.
Armed with the bullywug's signature spear and a set of poison darts, a bullywug hunter is capable of bringing down large prey with a well-placed shot of its blowgun.

entries.name: Bullywugs
entries: Brutish, frog-like amphibians, bullywugs are a primitive race of hunter gatherers, held together by a corrupt aristocracy and caste system. Bullywug society is defined by these separate castes, and a bullywug in a lower caste always tries to improve its station.

A member of the caste right below the chieftain, a bullywug shaman is often almost as powerful within bullywug society as the chieftain himself. Armed with potent druidic magic, a bullywug shaman is able create havoc on the battlefield, unleashing giant frogs and toads to attack the enemy as well as entering the fray themselves.

entries.name: Bullywugs
entries: Brutish, frog-like amphibians, bullywugs are a primitive race of hunter gatherers, held together by a corrupt aristocracy and caste system. Bullywug society is defined by these separate castes, and a bullywug in a lower caste always tries to improve its station.

When a succubus and a male human procreate, the result of this pairing is occasionally an alu-fiend, an always female cambion that takes more after its non-fiendish parent than most cambions. Outside of their large, leathery wings, these creatures look almost entirely human. They lack the discolored skin, tails, and horns that identify most cambions, allowing them to pass themselves off as normal humans if they find a way to hide their wings.

entries.name: Products of Their Environment
entries: Alu-fiends are usually raised by their mothers, and end up just as evil as their fiendish parent. In some cases, however, an alu-fiend raised might be raised by a good, nurturing person, leading them away from their evil natures. While an alu-fiend rarely becomes truly good or altruistic, they do not always become wholly evil.

entries.name: Cambions
entries: Cambions, as the general term for a half-fiend, encompass a variety of possible pairings. These pairings, dependent mostly on the fiendish parent, can produce offspring that end up quite different from the more general cambion. Cambions sired from greater beings, like arch-devils and arch-demons, might end up overwhelmingly powerful once they come of age. Those sired by weaker fiends, however, could end up relatively weak, and in rare cases, might be able to resist the evil nature of their fiendish parents.

Sometimes called the Prince of Pleasure, Graz'zt is one of the most humanoid demons of the abyss, and he is the archdemon who's most fond of siring mortal children. Beautiful and charismatic, the spawn of Graz'zt become particularly powerful as they come of age, and they are capable of greater feats than their most of their kin.

Characterized by their ashen skin, pointed ears, and cloven hoofs, the unearthly beauty of Graz'zt's children is pervaded by a subtle wrongness. While the appearance of their true form is magically mesmerizing, once the initial impression wears off onlookers often begin to take notice of the fiendish features that pervade the spawn's form.

While these cambions usually prefer to utilize their charm and acts of subtle deception in their quest for power, they are highly capable fighters when pressed. Powerful spell casters and capable of teleporting across the battlefield at-will, these creatures can manipulate their surroundings and the people around them to gain the upper hand, all as they cleave apart their foes with both strength and precision.
One of the signature abilities of the spawn of graz'zt is their ability to take the shape of other humanoids. They utilize this to deceive and impersonate others, much like a doppelganger.

entries.name: Cambions
entries: Cambions, as the general term for a half-fiend, encompass a variety of possible pairings. These pairings, dependent mostly on the fiendish parent, can produce offspring that end up quite different from the more general cambion. Cambions sired from greater beings, like arch-devils and arch-demons, might end up overwhelmingly powerful once they come of age. Those sired by weaker fiends, however, could end up relatively weak, and in rare cases, might be able to resist the evil nature of their fiendish parents.

Orcus is not well known for siring cambions, but those he has sired have become powerful warlords and leaders. Inhumanly strong and naturally talented in the arts of necromancy, the spawn of Orcus are destined for seats of power. In the mortal realm they might preside over dark kingdoms, ruling over mortals with an iron fist and raising armies of undead to do their bidding. Those that live in the abyss might lead armies of demons, bowing to no one but Orcus himself.

The spawn of orcus take on a particularly intimidating appearance, with large, twisting horns, charcoal-black skin, dark wings, a long, whip-like tail, and a great stature. They grow quickly after birth, and reach their eventual height of approximately 11 feet once they reach 10 years of age.

entries.name: Pawns of Orcus
entries: Unlike Graz'zt, Orcus does not procreate for pleasure. The few cambions he has sired were created to serve him in one way or another, always advancing his goals whether they intended to or not. Some might become his generals, while others serve as the leaders of proxy kingdoms in the mortal realm.

entries.name: Dread Necromancers
entries: The spawn of Orcus are naturally talented in necromancy, like the archdemon that sired them.They attempt to raise the undead wherever they go, sometimes for their own use, but often to simply spread chaos throughout the land. They commonly animate whatever bodies they find, not caring to reassert their control once the 24 hours have elapsed.

entries.name: Cambions
entries: Cambions, as the general term for a half-fiend, encompass a variety of possible pairings. These pairings, dependent mostly on the fiendish parent, can produce offspring that end up quite different from the more general cambion. Cambions sired from greater beings, like arch-devils and arch-demons, might end up overwhelmingly powerful once they come of age. Those sired by weaker fiends, however, could end up relatively weak, and in rare cases, might be able to resist the evil nature of their fiendish parents.

monsterFluff.name: Tangle Crawler
entries: As deadly as they are monstrous, carrion crawlers are not an uncommon foe for those that explore damp caves and decrepit ruins. Known for their long, whip-like tentacles, these creatures generally hide in subterranean environments, clinging to dungeon or cavern ceilings while their tentacles probe the air, searching for any sign of a potential victim.

Not all carrion crawlers are the same, however. While all of them share the same general hunting patterns and behaviors, and can be identified by their array of tentacles, some carrion crawlers are specialized in hunting a specific prey, or have adapted to unique environments.

Often making their homes in deep jungle ruins or within the overgrowth of an expansive forest, tangle crawlers are exceptionally large carrion crawlers, capable of ambushing and hunting down much larger prey than their smaller cousins. Often hunting down creatures as large as elephants, a tangle crawler is an intimidating sight for any adventurer.

A tangle crawler has the same general characteristics as a standard carrion crawler. They have long, constantly moving tentacles, each capable of delivering a paralyzing poison to their potential victims. They also have the same, centipede-like body, with rows of short legs that can easily stick to the walls and ceilings of caves and similar environments. The main differences in their appearance arise from their distinct green coloring, allowing them to camouflage in more forested areas, and their thick protective plating.

entries.name: Ambush Predators
entries: Tangle crawlers use their improved camouflage and other adaptations to their forested habitat to better ambush their victims, paralyzing them and pulling them to their death. Despite their great size, a tangle crawler can easily conceal itself within the piles of leaves and loose dirt that cover the forest floor. It is there that they wait, always testing the air for any unusual scent. They might also allow one of their tentacles to breach the surface, utilizing it as bait for large animals that might mistake it for a giant earthworm or constrictor snake.

Individuals that choose to leave their tribe and seek out civilization often become powerful warriors, using their natural strength combined with professional training to reach heights of physical ability that few humanoids can match. These centaurs may choose to become knights, lending their strength to a humanoid civilization, religious order, or similar cause. In these positions they act as natural leaders, capable of directing soldiers and rallying them in battle.

A centaur knight does not often travel alone, but they are usually the only one of their kind among their companions. While occasionally two or three centaurs might leave their tribe together, such an occurrence is a rarity among rarities.

entries.name: Centaurs
entries: Strong and proud, centaurs can make for formidable warriors and trustworthy allies. While most centaurs live their lives as tribal nomads, a few individuals break that mold, either seeking out nearby civilization or delving even deeper into the lonesome, vast forests of the world.

A centaur marksman is an master archer that has learned to weave natural magic into their shots. While some exceptional centaurs have managed to master this style of fighting on their own, most are in part taught by elven arcane archers. As the edges of a centaur's domain often intersect with the fringes of elven society, interactions between these two races are not uncommon. While this form of archery is similar to arcane archery, centaur marksmen use their innate magic, rather than learned magic, to augment their abilities.

entries.name: Centaurs
entries: Strong and proud, centaurs can make for formidable warriors and trustworthy allies. While most centaurs live their lives as tribal nomads, a few individuals break that mold, either seeking out nearby civilization or delving even deeper into the lonesome, vast forests of the world.

Spiritcallers, also called beastcallers or simply shamans, are centaurs that have connected themselves to the natural world, joining their souls with those of the creatures of the forest. These individuals live their lives as solitary hermits, protectors of the wooded landscapes they call home. In their solitude they learned to control and hone their natural magic, allowing them to summon beast-like spirits and befriend whatever beasts they might encounter. While they live far from centaur tribes, a spiritcaller may be sought out by other centaurs, or even humanoids, for the knowledge and wisdom that they possess.

entries.name: Centaurs
entries: Strong and proud, centaurs can make for formidable warriors and trustworthy allies. While most centaurs live their lives as tribal nomads, a few individuals break that mold, either seeking out nearby civilization or delving even deeper into the lonesome, vast forests of the world.

A centaur wildling is centaur that has completely abandoned civilization, even shunning the tribal nomadism of centaur society. Shaped by the harsh wilderness, these centaurs have become more savage and barbaric than their kin, and more willing to resort to violence. Skilled in battle, a wildling can often single-handedly take out bandit operations and hunt down dangerous monsters. While they've distanced themselves from their tribes, centaur wildlings still often help their tribe indirectly through their hunts and quests.

entries.name: Centaurs
entries: Strong and proud, centaurs can make for formidable warriors and trustworthy allies. While most centaurs live their lives as tribal nomads, a few individuals break that mold, either seeking out nearby civilization or delving even deeper into the lonesome, vast forests of the world.

A cerynitis, also called a golden hind, is a divine guardian created by a benevolent nature deity. Born as the offspring of a normal deer through divine intervention, a cerynitis grows quickly into its celestial form, defined by its brilliant, golden antlers, unnatural size, and breathtaking speed.

entries.name: Divine Creations
entries: When a deity brings a cerynitis into the material plane, it does so with a purpose in mind. Cerynitises are born in times of need, often for the protection of a sacred place, artifact, or, rarely, a person.

As cerynitises are not born at their full strength, there can often be a significant delay between the event that triggers their birth and their subsequent aid. Once born, a cerynitis grows to its full size in approximately two months, and it is only then that it seeks out its appointed duty.
Once its mission is complete, a cerynitis lives out the rest of its fairly short lifespan, usually less than a decade, still seeking to help the good hearted and destroy the evils of the world.

entries.name: Unearthly Speed
entries: To onlookers, the passage of a cerynitis looks like nothing more than a blur of golden light. Near uncatchable, a cerynitis is at its best in open plains and sparse forests, where it can travel across vast distances to reach the things it needs to protect or the enemies it must vanquish. It is this unparalleled speed that makes a cerynitis a powerful mount, though they are only willing to carry noble humanoids.

entries.name: Golden Antlers
entries: A cerynitis' antlers are made from both bone and gold, making them highly prized and sought after. A set of antlers can often sell for 2,500 gp or more.

Astral chimeras are the antithesis of Demogorgon's creations, brought into existence through the powers of ancient, goodaligned deities. An ordinary specimen resembles a large silver-furred beast, with blue skin, the forelimbs of a bird, and the hindquarters of a goat. Upon its shoulders sit two necks and two heads, one more feline and the other more canine.

entries.name: Relics of Past Gods
entries: Within the great, silvery seas of the astral plane float the petrified remains of dead gods, set adrift for millennia after their passing. While these beings are long deceased, some small remnants of their power still seep into the world. Occasionally, these remnants of power can combine with magic inherent to the astral plane, forming the creatures known as astral chimeras.

While these creatures are born in isolation, they do not stay in reclusion for long. Driven by their innate good nature, astral chimeras seek to travel through all planes of existence, vanquishing evil where they find it and assisting other creatures in their time of need.

entries.name: Endless Wanderers
entries: Astral chimeras are constantly moving from place to place, using their innate ability to planeshift and jaunt to and from the astral plane to make their way across the multiverse. In their travels, astral chimeras can gain a breadth of knowledge that few creatures can match.

When Demogorgon birthed chimeras into the material plane, demimaeras, also referred to as lesser chimeras, were also created. Lacking the draconic head and leathery wings of true chimeras, demimaeras instead have an alternate third head - a snake head on the end of their tail.

A demimaera's personality, like the typical chimera, is shaped by the worst aspects of its three parts. It has the same leonine territoriality and goat-like stubbornness, but it lacks the draconic greediness of typical chimeras that lead them to seek out hoards of gold and jewels. Instead, its snake head gives it a vengeful, vindictive streak that causes it to go to great lengths to kill those that it believes have wronged it. Creatures that steal a demimaera's food or manage to wound it and escape are tracked down and brought to a grisly end.

A maeragorgon is a chimera that Demogorgon has personally corrupted with abyssal magic, transforming it into a fiendish creature far crueler than any normal chimera. Stronger and more cunning than their lesser counterparts, maeragorgons serve directly under the Prince of Demons, and their power is comparable to that of type 5 or type 6 demons. Maeragorgons unquestioningly exercise the demon prince's will, serving as powerful guards or war beasts whenever the need arises.

Through their transformation maeragorgons are gifted with fiendish abilities. They can cause their claws to leave trails of flame, their horns to coat with ice, and their fanged maw to secrete a deadly poison. A maeragorgon uses these gifts to become an unpredictable opponent that can change up its tactics on a whim. In combat, maeragorgons stay constantly mobile, landing to quickly take out a foe and then lifting back into the sky with a burst of flame. More intelligent than lesser chimeras, a maeragorgon will use its speed and powerful breath attack to keep itself out of harm's way, and knows when retreat is necessary.

entries.name: Demonic Mount
entries: A maeragorgon can serve as an exceptionally powerful mount, carrying upon its back high-ranking demons, death knights, and other vile creatures.

Although this blood-sucking carnivore is most well-known for its hunting of goats, sheep, and other farm animals, it preys on any creature that it is capable of killing. The victims of a chupacabra are sucked dry of their blood, all with three puncture wounds centered around a point on their chest or neck. When such victims are found on the edges of civilization, there is little that untrained, unprotected villagers can do to protect themselves or their livestock from such vicious monsters.

entries.name: Nocturnal Predators
entries: A chupacabra spends the daylight hours asleep, hidden in its swampy lair. Small prey—drained of blood—may be found in these lairs as evidence of their inhabitants, but its lair is otherwise indistinguishable from the hidey hole of a common beast. It is only at nightfall that these monstrous creatures awaken, ready to hunt for their next meal. Quiet on its feet, a chupacabra stalks the outskirts of a village, waiting for a suitable meal to show itself. Once the opportunity arises, a chupacabra darts out from its hiding place, ambushing its prey before they can react. When it completes its kill, it vanishes into the night as quickly as it came.

entries.name: Fueled by Blood
entries: While a chupacabra's taste for blood is commonly known among adventurers, lesser known are the magical effects fresh blood has on a chupacabra's body. As long as a chupacabra is able to suck the blood of a creature, it can close its wounds and greatly increase its stamina. Those that fight a chupacabra are often surprised by its increased speed and durability in combat.

monsterFluff.name: Brass Spider
entries: The brass spider is one of the larger gnomish creations, built for its offensive power and mobility. Although commonly called a spider, the contraption only has six legs, rather than eight. However, its brass body and head resembles that of a large spider, with decorative "fangs" and a protruding abdomen. Each of its six legs are made from sharpened, iron blades. These blades serve as effective weapons, and also allow the construct to climb near-vertical surfaces, forcibly stabbing its legs into a wall for grip.

In combat, a brass spider is well suited to taking on multiple opponents, making it especially useful in a large-scale conflict. The raw power within its legs allows its to jump into the fray, knocking down and skewering multiple opponents at once. A brass spider that manages to knock down an opponent can keep that creature in place, stabbing a leg through the creature's body or clothes straight into the ground beneath them.

entries.name: Clockworks
entries: Gnomish advances in mechanical and magical design have led to the creation of many unique clockwork contraptions. Some of these designs have become staples among Gnomish crafters, while others have faded into obscurity.

entries.name: Individual Designs
entries: {@footnote When Gnomes create clockworks, they often individualize their work, adding unique enhancements or occasionally making mistakes in the construction process.|A gnome artisan values an individualized clockwork more highly than a perfectly functioning one that copies too much from another creation. For that reason, even clockworks that fit established designs, such as those described here, are seldom identical.}

A clockwork can be customized by adding one of the following enhancements and one potential malfunction to its stat block. You can select randomly or choose a pair of modifications that fit the temperament of the clockwork's builder.

entries.caption: Clockwork Enhancements
rows: {@b Camouflaged.} The clockwork gains proficiency in {@skill Stealth} if it doesn't already have it. While motionless, it is indistinguishable from a stopped machine.
{@b Sensors.} The range of the clockwork's {@sense darkvision} becomes 120 feet, unless it is higher, and it gains proficiency in {@skill Perception} if it doesn't already have it.
{@b Improved Armor.} The clockwork's AC increases by 2.
{@b Increased Speed.} The clockwork's speed increases by 10 feet.
{@b Reinforced Construction.} The clockwork has resistance to force, lightning, and thunder damage.
{@b Self-Repairing.} If the clockwork starts its turn with at least 1 hit point, it regains 5 hit points. If it takes lightning damage, this ability doesn't function at the start of its next turn.
{@b Sturdy Frame.} The clockwork's hit point maximum increases by an amount equal to its number of Hit Dice.
{@b Suction.} The clockwork gains a climbing speed of 30 feet.
{@b Vocal Resonator.} The clockwork gains the ability to speak rudimentary Common or Gnomish (creator's choice).
{@b Water Propulsion.} The clockwork gains a swimming speed of 30 feet.
{@b Makeshift Wings.} The clockwork gains a flying speed equal to its walking speed. If the clockwork ends its turn in the air, it falls.

{@b Anti-magic Core.} The clockwork can cast {@spell counterspell} as a 3rd-level spell, using Wisdom as its spellcasting ability. Once it does so, it can't do so again until it completes a short or long rest.

entries.caption: Clockwork Malfunctions
rows: {@b Faulty Sensors.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clockwork's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork is {@condition blinded} until the end of its turn.
{@b Flawed Targeting.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clockwork's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork makes attack rolls with disadvantage until the end of its turn.
{@b Ground Fault.} The clockwork has vulnerability to lightning damage.

{@b Imprinting Loop.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clockwork's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork mistakes one creature it can see within 30 feet for its creator. The clockwork won't willingly harm that creature for 1 minute or until that creature attacks it or deals damage to it.
{@b Leaking Lubricant.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clockwork's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork gains 1 level of {@condition exhaustion} that it isn't immune to.

{@b Limited Steering.} The clockwork must move in a straight line. It can turn up to 90 degrees before moving and again at the midpoint of its movement. It can rotate freely if it doesn't use any of its speeds on its turn.

{@b Overactive Sense of Self-Preservation.} If the clockwork has half its hit points or fewer at the start of its turn in combat, roll a {@dice d6}. If you roll a 1, it retreats from combat. If retreat isn't possible, it continues fighting.
{@b Overheats.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clockwork's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork is {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its turn.
{@b Rusty Gears.} The clockwork has disadvantage on initiative rolls, and its speed decreases by 10 feet.
{@b Weak Armor.} The clockwork isn't immune to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine.
{@b Squeaky Gears.} The clockwork loses any proficiency in {@skill Stealth}, and has disadvantage on {@skill Stealth} checks.
{@b Brittle.} When the clockwork takes damage, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to half the damage it took. On a failed save, its speed is permanently reduced by 10 feet.

monsterFluff.name: Electrum Drake
entries: An electrum drake is a small clockwork construct built to protect its owner's treasures like a dragon protects its hoard. Dragon-like in appearance, though without wings, an electrum drake is equipped with two breath attacks: one that creates a burst of flame, and another that releases a paralyzing gas. The electrum drake utilizes both, depending on how its creator has programmed it to fight. Many are programmed to first try to incapacitate opponents, only using their deadly flame breath if the situation escalates.

entries: Gnomish advances in mechanical and magical design have led to the creation of many unique clockwork contraptions. Some of these designs have become staples among Gnomish crafters, while others have faded into obscurity.

{@b Limited Steering.} The clockwork must move in a straight line. It can turn up to 90 degrees before moving and again at the midpoint of its movement. It can rotate freely if it doesn't use any of its speeds on its turn.

{@b Overactive Sense of Self-Preservation.} If the clockwork has half its hit points or fewer at the start of its turn in combat, roll a {@dice d6}. If you roll a 1, it retreats from combat. If retreat isn't possible, it continues fighting.
{@b Overheats.} Roll a {@dice d6} at the start of the clockwork's turn. If you roll a 1, the clockwork is {@condition incapacitated} until the end of its turn.
{@b Rusty Gears.} The clockwork has disadvantage on initiative rolls, and its speed decreases by 10 feet.
{@b Weak Armor.} The clockwork isn't immune to bludgeoning, piercing, and slashing damage from nonmagical attacks that aren't adamantine.
{@b Squeaky Gears.} The clockwork loses any proficiency in {@skill Stealth}, and has disadvantage on {@skill Stealth} checks.
{@b Brittle.} When the clockwork takes damage, it must make a Constitution saving throw with a DC equal to half the damage it took. On a failed save, its speed is permanently reduced by 10 feet.

monsterFluff.name: Greater Cockatrice
entries: Cockatrices are ferocious, avian monsters, resembling a horrifying hybrid of bird and reptile. Their glowing, otherworldly eyes tell of their magical nature, and even the glare of a smaller, common cockatrice strikes fear. But there exist far greater threats than the common cockatrice. Some cousins of the cockatrice pose a far greater threat.

The man-eating greater cockatrice is a creature of unnatural origin. Produced from the egg of a common cockatrice that is subsequently incubated in the belly of a giant toad, a greater cockatrice can grow to sizes far larger than a man. Ferocious and untamable, greater cockatrices are only rarely born. As the strange circumstances that lead to their hatching are hardly natural, these creatures are only born through the will of other creatures. Evil humanoids might seek to hatch a greater cockatrice, but the creatures are hardly useful as guards, mounts, or companions. A greater cockatrice feels no compassion for a creature that raises it, and is just as likely to kill them as it is to kill their enemies.

entries.name: Gaze of Death
entries: Some superstitions claim that a cockatrice can kill with its gaze alone. A seasoned adventurer knows this to be a myth, but myths often hold grains of truth. While regular cockatrices have no such ability, the gaze of a greater cockatrice causes onlookers bodies to wither away, with weaker creatures dying from a single glare.

Those that face a greater cockatrice in battle must be careful not to look the creature in the eye, while also avoiding the monster's deadly beak. Like their smaller counterparts, a single bite can lead to petrification. In some cases, however, petrification is not a death sentence. A greater cockatrice prefers to eat non-petrified creatures, and may leave a petrified creature with only a missing limb upon its awakening.

In their long lifetimes, couatls may lose sight of their original goals. With their divine mandates long fulfilled or failed, a couatl might set out to achieve its own goals, and in process slowly distance themselves the benevolent teachings of their god. When such a couatl senses its impending death, there is a chance of them seeking to change their fate. Through the powers of dark magic, a couatl can escape the permanency of death—for a price.

In granting itself immortality, a couatl loses as much as it gains. Its colorful wings wither into stumps, incapable of flight, its serpentine body becomes covered in thick feathers, and its eyes take on a deep crimson hue. They lose all that was left of their compassion, and their divine powers are replaced with necromantic abilities.

A quetzalcouatl is a couatl, or the descendant of a couatl, that managed to particularly impress their ancient god. For succeeding in their divine task and then going far beyond what was asked of them, a couatl might be rewarded with a gift of divine power. Such a couatl becomes gifted with magic that controls the wind, and its body grows to a truly monumental size. While their manner is still gentle and kind, quetzalcouatls have enough power to take on greater tasks and sway historyaccording to the will of their god.

A quetzalcouatl is granted a lifespan far longer than normal couatl, and they use long life well in pursuit of their goals. These creatures are still mortal, however, and seek out mates near the end of their life to continue their sacred bloodline.

The curious, scuttling crysmal resembles a scorpion built from colorful gemstones. Native to the Elemental Plane of Earth, crysmals search the winding caverns of that plane for gems and valuable stones. These minerals serve as the basis of their diet, and a crysmal also uses them to reproduce. In order to create offspring, a crysmal imbues a conglomeration of stones and crystals with psionic energy. In their long lives, usually lasting well over a century, a crysmal does little more than eat and reproduce.

entries.name: Delver's Bane
entries: Some crysmals manage to make their way to the material plane, where they are of particular nuisance. Miners and cave explorers learn to fear these creatures, as they will often attack humanoids in search of the gemstones they might be carrying. Often, it is a better idea to give up some gemstones and run than it is to fight one of these creatures, especially if they are encountered in a group.

entries.name: Elemental Absorption
entries: The stone that makes up a chrysmal's tail absorbs the energy of cold, fire, and lightning based attacks, making those damage types ineffective and charging the crysmal with elemental power. In this way, a crysmal can attempt to exploit a creature's weaknesses by changing its damage type, though another creature can achieve the opposite by damaging the chrysmal with a damage type that creature is resistant to.

entries.name: Psionic Hierarchy
entries: Crysmals generally live in small packs of three to five, with one of the pack's members acting as its leader. The leader generally is the chrysmal most proficient with its psionic abilities, which is in turn the most well-fed among the group. Crysmals fed more precious stones develop stronger psionic abilities, while crysmals that go unfed gradually lose their psionic capabilities.

When a cyclops mates with a human, goliath, hobgoblin, bugbear, or orc, the result is a half-cyclops. Such a pairing is rare, as the difference in size between most humanoids and cyclopes is usually too large for mating to be possible. A particularly young, runtish cyclops and a particularly large humanoid may be able to mate, however, though a human mother rarely survives childbirth.
Once born, a half-cyclops grows quickly, reaching heights of 6-7 feet by age 8. An adult half-cyclops stands close to 10 feet tall and weighs 600 pounds on average.

Possessing giant-like strength combined with greater intelligence, half-cyclopes make for powerful warriors and adventurers, though they are often shunned by humanoid societies that judge them as unintelligent savages.

An infernal cyclops is a minion of Asmodeus, created to further that archdevil's goals in the material plane. Gifted with demonic cruelty and infernal abilities, these creatures were first created millenia ago, twisted from regular cyclopes into terrifying, misshapen forms. Though most cyclopes that underwent this transformation died in the process, the few that survived were granted strength rivaling even the most powerful giants of the world. Over time, this species has been twisted so far from normal cyclopes as to be completely unrecognizable, save for their singular, bright red eye.

In battle, an infernal cyclops wields both a giant-sized club as well as a long whip imbued with hellfire, which it uses to great effect. With a shrill, uncharacteristic shriek, the creature can stop foes in their tracks. But its most dangerous weapon is its eye—with a look, an infernal cyclops can unleash a ray of hellfire that annihilates whatever it strikes.

entries.name: Notes: Using the Infernal Cyclops
entries: The infernal cyclops is meant to be used in an environment with ample amounts of cover. The cyclops' eye ray deals a considerable amount of damage, but its delay means that players have the opportunity to duck behind cover before the ray fires. As the ray always fires at the start of the cyclops' turn, before the cyclops has a chance to move to a better firing position, mobile players can avoid ever taking a hit. The only time a highly mobile player, like a rogue, should be at risk of being hit by the eye ray is after being stunned by the cyclops' shriek, or after being immobilized in some other way.
Also consider making much of the available cover destructible, so that the eye ray becomes harder to avoid as the fight progresses and cover becomes more scarce.

Lastly, keep in mind that the players can choose to intentionally fail the save, allowing them to protect allies that can't make it into cover in time (such as players stunned by the cyclops' shriek).

A so-called primal cyclops is actually a completely unrelated species of giant to the normal cyclops, but their shared characteristic of a single eye makes these two creatures often confused. A primal cyclops is part giant, part elemental, as rock-like armored plates sprout from its arms and backside. Its hands are overly large, even considering its colossal stature, and its fingers are ended by sharp, stone-like claws.

entries.name: Reclusive
entries: A primal cyclops lives alone, far from other members of it kind and even farther from anything that could be called civilization. For most of their lives, a primal cyclops lives only with the animals that it keeps, which include both farm animals like sheep and cows, as well as hunting animals like dire wolves. Primal cyclopes are known to get quite attached to some of the animals they hunt with, and won't hesitate to kill any creature that harms or kills one of its hunting companions.

The only time a primal cyclops seeks out another one of its kind is when it wishes to mate. When the time is right, a primal cyclops sets out across the wilderness to find a mate. Mating between these creatures is a loveless affair, and they raise their young only the minimum amount necessary before releasing them to fend for their own.

entries.name: Keen-Nosed
entries: Primal cyclopes have a keen sense of smell, especially when it comes to the scent of blood. While their eyesight is poor, like other cyclops, their sense of smell makes up for it. Primal cyclopes can track down wounded creatures for miles, and can pinpoint the exact location of nearby bleeding creatures, even if they have no way to see them.

spell.name: Animate Construct

m.text: the inanimate form of the construct, which must be worth at least an amount of gold equal to 200 + 800 multiplied by the construct's challenge rating

entries: After spending the casting time writing magical runes and symbols along the inanimate form of the construct, you create an animated construct with a challenge rating of 1 or less that cannot cast spells. This spell can target any non-animated object that can be animated, such as a weapon, armor, or the base of a homunculus (the DM has the creature's statistics). When you cast the spell, you give the construct a basic command that it follows for the duration of its existence, such as "guard this area" or "protect me."
If the construct is ever reduced to 0 hit points, you must spend half of its material cost to repair it. Otherwise, it can be repaired with {@spell mending} over the duration of a long rest.

entriesHigherLevel.name: At Higher Levels
entries: When you cast this spell using certain higher-level spell slots, you can animate an object with a higher challenge rating: 2 with a 5th-level slot, 3 with a 7th-level slot, and 4 with a 9th-level slot.
